message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prominent atrophy of the caudate nucleus suggests the patient has Huntington’s disease, which is caused by repeats of the trinucleotide CAG. The other options are associated with different genetic disorders.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and MRI findings suggest Huntington’s disease, which is caused by an expansion of the CAG trinucleotide repeat.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of gradually worsening tics and difficulty walking, along with an MRI showing prominent caudate nucleus atrophy indicate Huntington’s disease, which is caused by repeats of CAG trinucleotides. None of the other options are associated with Huntington’s disease.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and MRI findings suggest Huntington's disease, which is caused by the repeats of CAG trinucleotides.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The prominent atrophy of the caudate nucleus suggests Huntington’s disease, which is caused by a repeat of the CAG trinucleotide.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and MRI findings suggest Huntington Disease, which is caused by repeats of the CAG trinucleotide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The tri-nucleotide repeat disorder that causes prominent caudate nucleus atrophy and motor difficulties is Huntington’s disease, which is caused by repeats of CAG in the huntingtin gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and MRI results suggest Huntington's disease, which is caused by an expansion of the CAG trinucleotide repeat in the huntingtin (HTT) gene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including gradually worsening tics and difficulty walking, with prominent caudate atrophy, suggest Huntington disease. Huntington disease is caused by repeats of the CAG trinucleotide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and brain MRI suggest the patient has Huntington’s disease, which is caused by a trinucleotide expansion of CAG in the Huntingtin gene.
